user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGive:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGive(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_mutex_internal_record_t *mutex;
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;
    osal_id_t                   self_task;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        mutex = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_mutex_table, token);

        self_task = OS_TaskGetId();

        if (!OS_ObjectIdEqual(mutex->last_owner, self_task))
        {
            OS_DEBUG("WARNING: Task %lu giving mutex %lu while owned by task %lu\n", OS_ObjectIdToInteger(self_task),
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(sem_id), OS_ObjectIdToInteger(mutex->last_owner));
        }

        mutex->last_owner = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

        return_code = OS_MutSemGive_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGive:
typedef struct
{
    char      obj_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t last_owner;
} OS_mutex_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_mutex_internal_record_t OS_mutex_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_MutSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Unlock the mutex
     */
    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&(impl->id));
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId(void)
{
    osal_id_t task_id;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();

    return task_id;
}
...
static inline bool OS_ObjectIdEqual(osal_id_t object_id1, osal_id_t object_id2)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id1) == OS_ObjectIdToInteger(object_id2));
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not include other fragments for investigation because they clearly require non-const pointers or already use const where appropriate: 

- OS_MutSemGive_Impl is declared to take a const OS_object_token_t *token (OS_MutSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)); this already follows the rule where possible. 

- The local pointer 'mutex' in OS_MutSemGive is used to modify the object (mutex->last_owner = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;), so the pointed-to type must be mutable and therefore should not be const. 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById(..., &token) and the subsequent OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx) clearly write into the token (token->obj_idx and token->obj_id are assigned), so those functions must accept non-const pointers. 

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(...) and OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token) are transaction control routines that conceptually modify token or transaction state; while TransactionCancel was included in the suspicious list (because its implementation might be worth checking), other places that clearly mutate token were not included because mutation justifies non-const parameters. 

- pthread_mutex_unlock(&(impl->id)) operates on a pthread mutex object and the API requires a mutable pthread_mutex_t *, so const qualification is not appropriate there. 

Thus I limited suspicious entries to places where a pointer-to-non-const is passed but it is unclear from the shown code whether the pointee is actually modified (and therefore whether the parameter could legally be made const).
